items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall within the catchment. This information is correct as of 14:45 on Tuesday 1st October. The causeway at Earith has approximately 29 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 108cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 74 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Wednesday 2 October 2024.

This flood alert remains in force due to the combination of wave action and windblown spray on the coast tomorrow, Wednesday 02/10/2024. Flooding of low-lying land, promenades and roads is possible between 6:15am and 8:15am on Wednesday 02/10/2024. Areas most at risk include the the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston particularly Bridlington South Pier and the Bridlington Lifeboat Station. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday 02/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: Heavy rain is currently falling in the Peterborough area which is causing the river levels to rise on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 02/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

Strong onshore winds and large waves may lead to wave overtopping and spray around the high tide between 2:00 PM and 6:30 PM on 01/10/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 6:30 PM on 01/10/2024.

items.message:

Flooding is possible around the high tide between 2:00 PM and 6:30 PM on 01/10/2024.
Significant volumes of overtopping are current forecast. Historically these volumes have impacted businesses at Seaham marina.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow morning between 2:00 AM and 6:00 AM on 02/10/2024. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads near Seaham marina as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will update this message by 6.30pm on 01/10/2024, or if the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Witham area. This means that the River Witham is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the afternoon today, Tuesday 01/10/2024 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Tuesday's late evening tide at 23:45 on 01/10/2024 is forecast to be lower than recent days, but will still be accompanied by strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 5.64 metres Chart Datum (2.59 mAOD) at Littlehampton. No more than minimal flood impacts are expected. Very similar tide levels are forecast for the next five days. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will reissue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

River levels are rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible throughout today and tomorrow, Wednesday 2 October 2024. Areas most at risk are around the Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall. The forecast is for further rain today and tomorrow. River levels are expected to continue to rise over the next few hours. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 02/10/24.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston remains very high, but is now slowly falling. Through Tuesday, flooding will continue to affect fields, roads and gardens, including North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly. The Bull River through Hellingly remains higher than normal, with flood impacts likely affecting fields and roads. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible Tuesday afternoon, but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. Flood impacts in Hellingly should ease by Tuesday afternoon. In Alfriston, flood impacts could continue until Wednesday afternoon. However, another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Plan to avoid routes vulnerable to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 02/10/2024

The Powdermill Stream through Crowhurst has fallen significantly following Monday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads should continue to ease in Crowhurst through Tuesday (01/10/2024). No flood impacts are expected in Bulverhythe, where the Combe Haven will remain higher than normal until the weekend. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon (01/10/2024), but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. The river should continue to slowly fall, returning to normal in Crowhurst by Wednesday afternoon (02/10/2024). Another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept close by, and ready for installation, in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if property flooding is possible.

River levels remain high but are now falling on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is still possible through Tuesday and into Wednesday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

The River Ouse is still higher than normal near Barcombe, but is slowly falling, following Monday's rain. Small amounts of flood water could continue to affect roads, including Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and Barcombe Mills road. Minor flooding could also affect fields near the Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills, but all impacts should ease by Tuesday afternoon 01/10/2024. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon, but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. River levels should fall, or remain low through to the end of the week. However, another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads may continue to be affected by flooding, including Barcombe Mills road. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this message if new instances of property flooding is possible.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and the Cadnam River at Cadnam is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 25mm of rain has been recorded in Romsey, this is a modest amount but follows 9 days of persistent wet weather, where more than a month’s rain has been recorded. From 10:30 this morning (30/09/2024), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. Rain clears eastwards by lunchtime and a dry afternoon follows. Tomorrow (Tuesday 01/10/2024) only a small amount of rain (10mm) is forecast. The rest of the week should remain relatively dry. The river will rise until at least 14:00 this afternoon (30/09/2024). As it peaks it will not cause property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 01/10/2024.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are slowly rising on the River Loddon following a period of sustained rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 01/10/2024, especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads affecting access to properties. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. 

We will continue to monitor the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 01/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Buildwas river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight today, 01/10/24 and into tomorrow morning, 02/10/24.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Predicted Peaks:- Buildwas 3.3m to 3.5m on Wednesday morning 02/10/24 at 00:30.    

No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to fall from tomorrow morning, 02/10/24. Flood alert conditions are not expected at other gauge locations. Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation closely. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated  by 10am on 02/10/24, or as the situation changes.

Following the heavy rainfall which was recorded on Sunday and Monday, the water level in the Eastern Yar is now slowly falling. Currently we do not expect impacts at Alverstone. At Sandown, the river may still be causing minor flooding to Moreton Common and Golf Links Road, although this should improve later this evening. Today (Tuesday 01/10/2024) and tomorrow (Wednesday 02/10/2024), a small amount of rain is forecast (up to 10mm) each day. This may cause a small rise in level over the next 48 hours, but this is not expected to cause significant impacts. The rest of the working week should remain relatively dry, giving the river a chance to recover. We have checked that the Bembridge sluice is operating normally. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be removed or updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 02/10/2024.

This flood warning remains in force due to high river levels following Monday's heavy and persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Woodhouse Mill and properties on Furnace Lane and Retford Road. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout today and no further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not drive through floodwater.
 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message as the situation changes. This message will be updated by 18:00 on 01/10/2024.

This flood warning remains in force due to high river levels following Monday's heavy and persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Beighton, including Woodhouse Lane and Rotherham Road and Crown Works Industrial Estate.
 
River levels at the Woodhouse Ings regulator are still rising slowly, but the rate has slowed and should peak soon. Upstream levels at Killamarsh have now peaked and are starting to fall.
 
We are expecting further rain today, but this will not be as heavy or prolonged as yesterday’s rainfall. We expect that this rain will keep river levels elevated at Woodhouse Mill. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout today and no further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not drive through floodwater.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston remains high, but is now falling, following Monday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens including The Old Clergy House, properties near Willows Car Park on North Street, River Lane and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. A Flood Alert remains in force to describe minor flood impacts. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon (01/10/2024), but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. The river should continue to fall through Tuesday, and should return nearer to normal by Wednesday afternoon (02/10/2024). However, another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this Flood Warning if property flooding is expected.
